questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with chronic fatigue is shown below. This marked finding is seen in all of the conditions except
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows Howell–Jolly bodies. They are not seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

They are small nuclear remnants seen as inclusions in red cells and are characteristic of asplenia. They are seen in the following conditions:

  • Sickle cell anaemia - due to auto splenectomy
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia post-splenectomy

questions.text:
Match the types of thalassemia with their most common mutations.
1. β+ thalassemia A. Terminator mutation
2. β0 thalassemia B. Gene deletion
3. α thalassemia C. Splicing mutation
questions.solution:
The most common types of mutations causing thalassemia are:

Thalassemia Most common mutation
β+ thalassemia Splicing mutation
β0 thalassemia Terminator mutation
α thalassemia Gene deletion

The different splicing mutations are:

  • Mutations that destroy the normal RNA splice junctions - completely prevent the production of normal β-globin mRNA resulting in β0-thalassemia
  • Mutations that create an ectopic splice site within an intron with normal splice regions - some normal β-globin mRNA is made resulting in β+ thalassemia

There are two subtypes of chain terminator mutations:

  • New stop codon within an exon
  • Small insertions or deletions that shift the mRNA reading frames

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: Which chromosome is affected in alpha-thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Chromosome 16 contains an identical pair of α-globin genes which is affected in alpha-thalassemia. This condition is due to decreased synthesis of alpha chains. 

The two β chains are encoded by a single β-globin gene on chromosome 11.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding α-thalassemia?

choices.text: Free β and γ chains are more soluble than free α chains
β tetramer is known as HbH
α chains are coded by a pair of genes
Hb Barts is the most severe form

questions.solution:
α chains are coded by 4 genes i.e. two pairs of genes located on chromosome 16.

Free β and γ chains are more soluble than free α chains. They also form more stable homotetramers. Hence, hemolysis and dyserythropoiesis in α thalassemia are less severe when compared to β thalassemia.

In HbH disease, excess β-globin chains form β4 tetramers. They are seen in older children with α-thalassemia.

Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of α-thalassemia. It is caused by the deletion of all four α-globin genes. This leads to excess γ-globin chains forming γ-globin tetramers (hemoglobin Barts).

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G3P2A0L0, in a consanguinous marriage, delivered a hydropic stillborn at 32 weeks of gestation.  Further evaluation revealed the presence of Hb Barts in the fetal blood. Which of the following globin chains tetramer is found in this condition?
questions.solution:
Hb Barts is a tetramer of γ-globin chains (γ4). This type of hemoglobin is seen in newborns with the most severe form of α-thalassemia and results in hemoglobin Barts hydrops fetalis. There is no production of α chains.

Hb Barts has a higher affinity for oxygen. This leads to intrauterine hypoxia, eventually leading to stillbirth.

The image given below shows (a) immature red cell precursors in peripheral smear and (b) stillborn hydropic infant in Hb Barts hydrops syndrome. 

In HbH disease, excess β-globin chains form β4 tetramers. They are seen in older children with α-thalassemia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old Chinese translator presents with fever, jaundice and splenomegaly. His Hb is 6 g% and peripheral smear with brilliant cresyl blue is given below. Which of the following globin chains would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of extravascular hemolysis (jaundice and splenomegaly) and peripheral smear showing golf ball cells is suggestive of HBH disease. It is a type of α thalassemia where the HbH is composed of tetramers of β chains (β4).

Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. It is more common in the Asian population. It usually manifests in the 1st year of life. It causes acute episodes of hemolysis when triggered by infections or oxidant drugs.

The decreased α chain production leads to a relative excess of β chains. This leads to the formation of HbH which has a high affinity for oxygen. Such RBCs are more prone to oxidation which causes precipitation of HbH to form golf ball inclusion bodies. This leads to increased sequestration and phagocytosis in the spleen.

questions.text: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. In thalassemia major, hematological findings in image 1 showing poikilocytes and image 3 showing target cells are seen. Image 2 showing Howell Jolly bodies are seen in post-splenectomy thalassemia patients and not in this case.

Hematological findings in thalassemia major include the following:

  • Anisopoikilocytosis
  • Target cells (codocytes)
  • Nucleated RBC’s
  • Dacrocytes
  • Basophilic stippling
  • Polychromatophilic cells

questions.text:
Given below is the hemogram of a patient. Calculate the Mentzer index.

Hb - 10 g%

RBC - 6 million/mm3

Reticulocyte count - 0.6%

MCV - 60 fL

MCH - 20 pg

Peripheral smear - microcytic hypochromic picture
questions.solution:
From the given hemogram, the Mentzer index is 10.

The formula for Mentzer index is MCV (fL) / TRBC (millions/mm3) i.e. 60/6 = 10

This index is used to differentiate between iron-deficiency anemia and beta-thalassemia trait. If the index is <13, it is most likely to be a thalassemia trait.

questions.text: The following test was performed with blood sample from a patient with anaemia. What is this test used for?
questions.solution:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings.

The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows:

  1. Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution.
  2. Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes.
  3. Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or lines.
NESTROFT Inference Reason
Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred
Lines not seen (positive) Thalassemia Stable RBC, unable to lyse

The image given below shows the NESTROFT.

questions.text:
A couple with a family history of thalassemia comes for genetic counselling. Their HPLC reports are given below. What is the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major?
Patient HbA2 levels
Husband 2.5%
Wife 4.9%
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major is 0%. 

From the given HPLC reports, the husband is normal (normal value of HbA2 is 2.5%±0.3%) and the wife has β thalassemia minor (HbA2 level 4.9%). This disease is transmitted with an autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the chance of their offspring having full blown thalassemia is zero. 

In β thalassemia minor, the Hb A2 levels are increased to 4–8%. This is due to an elevated ratio of δ chain to β chain synthesis. Hb F levels are generally normal or slightly increased.

Note: Increased HbF (diagnostic) and normal HbA2 levels are features of thalassemia major.

questions.text: A 25-year old man presents with chronic anemia and gall stones. His family history is significant for a similar illness. His peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the mode of the inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear showing spherocytes, along with the history, is suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. Inheritance of this condition is mainly autosomal dominant.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a structural RBC disorder making the RBCs more spheroid. The RBCs are less deformable and more vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. This decreases the lifespan of RBCs.

questions.text: What is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ankyrin is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis (HS).

The chief protein component of the RBC membrane skeleton is spectrin. It consists of two polypeptide chains, alpha and beta. These dimers associate with actin oligomers. The spectrin–actin skeleton is then connected to the cell membrane by two distinct interactions.

  • Ankyrin and band 4.2 binds spectrin to the transmembrane ion transporter, band 3
  • Protein 4.1 binds the tail of spectrin to the transmembrane protein glycophorin A

Defect in any of the components of the red cell membrane skeleton results in hereditary spherocytosis. The image given below shows the pathogenesis of this condition.

Note: Few one-liners on membrane skeleton -

  • Most abundant integral proteins - glycophorin, band 3 
  • Responsible for biconcave shape of RBC - spectrin
  • Most severe deficiency - spectrin
  • Hereditary elliptocytosis is due to deficiency of alpha spectrin
  • Mushroom cells appearance due to deficiency of band 3
  • Never involved in HS - glycophorin

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia, jaundice and splenomegaly shows pincer cells. Which protein deficiency is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution: Pincer cell or mushroom cell is seen in hereditary spherocytosis associated with deficiency of cytoskeletal protein band 3.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you least expect to see in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Hemoglobinuria is not seen in hereditary spherocytosis where extravascular hemolysis occurs. It is a feature of intravascular hemolysis. Pigment gallstones, pallor and splenomegaly can be seen in this condition.

Cinical features of extravascular hemolysis include:

  • Anaemia
  • Jaundice
  • Splenomegaly

Causes of extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anaemia

Note: G6PD deficiency and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia can cause both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

questions.text: What is the life span of affected red cells in patients with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution: The life span of affected red cells in hereditary spherocytosis is 10 to 20 days. The normal life span of RBC is 120 days.

questions.text: In a patient with hereditary spherocytosis, MCHC of 38 g/dL was noted. What could be the probable reason for this finding?
questions.solution:
Increased MCHC in hereditary spherocytosis is due to dehydration caused by the loss of K+ and H2O.

MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is given by the formula hemoglobin / PCV (g/dL). It indicates the amount of hemoglobin per unit volume.

Note:

  • MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is given by the formula PCV / RBC (fL). It denotes the size of the RBCs.
  • MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is given by the formula hemoglobin / RBC (pg). It quantifies the hemoglobin in the RBCs.

questions.text: In the following osmotic fragility curve, A occurs in _________.
questions.solution:
Osmotic fragility curve shifts to the right in hereditary spherocytosis.

In hereditary spherocytosis, the cells are spherocytic in normal plasma (0.9% NaCl) and hemolyse readily at higher concentrations than normal discoid red cells do, hence shifting the curve to the right.

Osmotic fragility is the susceptibility of the RBC to rupture under osmotic stress. In hypotonic solutions, RBCs swell to become spherical and eventually hemolyse. In the graph, the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red cells that have undergone hemolysis. When osmotic fragility is normal, red cells begin to hemolyse at 0.5% saline, with 50% of hemolysis occuring at 0.40-0.42% saline and complete hemolysis occuring at 0.35% saline as represented in the curve.

In thalassemia and sickle cell anemia on the other hand, the cells are resistant to hemolysis and don’t hemolyse unless the concentration of saline is very low, shifting the graph to the left.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presents with fever and jaundice for 5 days. On examination, splenomegaly is noted. Her lab reports are given below. What is the likely trigger to have caused this condition?

Hb - 5 g%

WBC - 1000 /mm3

Platelets - 45,000 /mm3

Peripheral smear shows spherocytes
questions.solution:
The given hemogram showing pancytopenia and spherocytes in peripheral smear is suggestive of aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis. It is usually triggered by parvovirus infection.

Parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This creates a transient arrest of erythropoiesis i.e. aplastic crisis as the life span of RBCs are shortened. The immune response clears the virus in 1-2 weeks.

Blood transfusions may be necessary during acute phases of the infection. This crisis can also occur in other hemolytic anaemias.

questions.text: Which amino acid lies at the sixth position of the beta chain of hemoglobin?
questions.solution:
Glutamate lies at the 6th position of the beta chain of hemoglobin.

Sickle-cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin. This leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.

questions.text: A blood sample is taken from a suspected case of sickle cell anaemia. Which of the following properties can be used to differentiate HbS from HbA?
questions.solution:
Solubility can be used to differentiate as HbS is less soluble than HbA. The function, stability and affinity of HbS are similar to that of HbA.

In HbS, glutamic acid, which is a polar amino acid, is replaced by a non-polar amino acid valine at the 6th position. HbS molecules have the tendency to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. This process converts the red cell cytosol from a free-flowing liquid into a viscous gel. This causes a change in the solubility of the hemoglobin.

The major pathologic manifestations of decreased solubility and polymerisation of HbS are chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was diagnosed to have heterozygous sickle cell trait. What will be the approximate percentage of HbS in this patient?
questions.solution:
In heterozygotes with sickle-cell trait, about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS. The rest of hemoglobin (60%) is HbA.

Sickle cell trait is a largely asymptomatic condition characterised by heterozygosity seen for HbS (sickle hemoglobin). As only a fraction of the Hb are HbS, polymerization leading to sickling only occurs in severe and prolonged hypoxia. Offsprings of 2 heterozygotes have a 1 in 4 chance of having sickle cell disease. 

In HbSC heterozygotes, HbS is 50% and HbC is 50%.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following combinations of beta-globin chains tend to have a more severe sickle cell disease?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the heterozygous combination of HbS and HbC causes a more severe form of the disease. Overall severity is more in homozygous HbS. 

Severity sequence is HbSS > HbSC > HbSA > HbSF.

In HbC, lysine is substituted for glutamate in the sixth amino acid residue of β-globin. The percentage of HbS is 50% in HbSC red cells and 40% in HbAS cells. Moreover, HbSC cells tend to lose salt and water and become dehydrated, which increases the intracellular concentration of HbS. Both of these factors increase the tendency for HbS to polymerize. As a result, individuals who are compound heterozygotes for HbS and HbC, have symptomatic sickling disorder (termed HbSC disease). However, it is milder than sickle cell disease (HbSS).

HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS even more than HbA. Hence, infants do not become symptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.

questions.text: In patients with sickle cell anaemia, which of the following factors promote sickling of RBC?
questions.solution:
HbC promotes the sickling of RBC, whereas HbF opposes it.

Factors that promote sickling are:

  • Increased MCHC
  • Hb C
  • Acidic pH
  • Hypoxia

HbF has a high affinity for oxygen than other hemoglobins. Hence, high oxygen content prevents sickling. HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS. So the infants do not become symptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.

questions.text: Which of the following reagents is used for sickling test?
questions.solution:
The reagent used for the sickling test is sodium metabisulfite. It is an oxygen-consuming reagent, which induces the sickling of red cells in the presence of HbS. 

Sickling test with sodium metabisulfite is used as a screening test for sickle cell anaemia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with fever and severe pain in her hands and feet. There is no history of trauma. Her lab reports reveal Hb to be 8.2 g/dL and peripheral smear as shown below. Which of the following parasitic infections is this condition protective against?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sickle cell anaemia. HbS gives protection against Plasmodium falciparum malaria. 

Hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of bones of hands and feet is a severe acute inflammatory response seen in sickle cell anaemia. It is caused by vaso-occlusive episodes leading to ischemia and finally infarction of the distal portions of the extremities.

Sickle cells impair the formation of membrane knobs containing a protein made by P. falciparum called PfEMP-1. This decreases the adherence of infected red cells to the endothelium.

Individuals with sickle cell trait are significantly less likely to have severe disease or to die from malaria. It is because of the increased phagocytosis of sickled cells in the spleen, which keeps the parasite load down.

questions.text: What happens to the severity of hemolytic anaemia in concurrent sickle cell anaemia and α-thalassemia?
questions.solution:
The concurrence of sickle cell anaemia and α-thalassemia results in less severe hemolytic anaemia.

Sickle cell anaemia is caused by point mutations in β globin synthesis leading to defective HbS synthesis. When these RBCs release oxygen, the HbS polymerises leading to membrane distortion

Thalassemia is due to germline mutations causing decreased globin chain synthesis (α or β). Since these diseases have a different pathogenesis, they can occur concurrently.

In alpha-thalassemia, the concentration of hemoglobin is decreased. Therefore the concentration of HbS in sickle cell anaemia is also decreased. Since HbS molecules should be close to each other for polymerization to occur. Since there is a decreased concentration of HbS in alpha-thalassemia, the HbS molecules are far apart. So there is a decreased polymerization of HbS and therefore less severity of the disease.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient with sickle cell anaemia presents with fever and malaise. IgM ELISA confirms a parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following crises will you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Aplastic crisis in sickle cell anaemia is caused by parvovirus B19. It is a transient arrest of erythropoiesis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills red cell precursors. It occurs in sickle cell disease and other hemolytic anaemias.

Vaso-occlusive crises (pain crises) are episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region. The most commonly involved sites are the bones, lungs, liver, brain, spleen, and penis. Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs. It typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Pulmonary inflammation may cause blood flow to become sluggish and “spleenlike,” leading to sickling and vaso-occlusion. 

Sequestration crises occur in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Both sequestration crises and acute chest syndrome may be fatal and sometimes require prompt treatment with exchange transfusions.

questions.text: During USG examination in a patient with hemolytic anemia, the spleen was not visualized. There is no past history of trauma or surgery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Non-visualisation of the spleen on routine USG is suggestive of autosplenectomy, which is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis.

In children with sickle cell anaemia, there is moderate splenomegaly. This is due to red pulp congestion caused by the entrapment of sickled red cells. As age advances, chronic erythrostasis produces hypoxic damage and infarcts. By adulthood, the spleen is reduced to a band of fibrous tissue. This process is called autosplenectomy.
